Comment_Remarks: Study of the coastal change since Antiquity suggests the site was located c. 3.5 kilometres from the sea at the time. Adulis is in fact the only site in the publication which was more or less surveyed properly. The island is probably to be equated with Orien_, which is mentioned in the Periplus of the Erythrean Sea. It is suggested it became the port for Adulis after Diodoros Island went out of use after the early first century AD, located 24 km. NE from Adulis. The island is mentioned in the Periplus of the Erythrean Sea, yet its harbour is likely to have silted or otherwise went out of use after the early first century AD, whereafter Orien_ became the port for Adulis, located some 5 kilometres SE from Adulis.
An Iron Age tell, obviously with later occupation.

Tel Mor is believed to have been the harbour of Azotos/Ashdod, and was/is located some 2 kilometres inland along the north bank of the navigable Nahal Lachish (Wadi Sukreir).

This ancient site lies about 3,5 km. east of the Dead Sea, above and east of Ghor el-Haditha, 200 metres below sea level on the south bank of the Wadi ibn Hammad.

Late Roman-Early Byzantine fort located near the 'En Boqeq oasis on the north side of the Nahal Boqeq valley and on the southwest shore of the Dead Sea, as part of the limes Palestinae.

One of the cities of the Dekapolis.
This site was apparently famous for its hot springs, which are recorded by Flavius Josephus, the site, represented by 'Byzantine' occupation, is also shown on the Madaba Map.
Modern-day Qanawat, 'member' of the Dekapolis, joined to the provincia Arabia in the late second century AD, it was the see of a bishop in the fourth and fifth centuries AD.
The remains of two buildings were found: one church and one  probable bath-building, as well as a millstone within the village proper.
